references: Figure 1: Country distribution. Distribution of country of origin for the articles in the full dataset (A) and in each of the splits (B-D). A and B share the color bar in the top row; C and D share the color bar in the bottom row. Detailed counts are available in Supplementary Tables 1-3

The dataset was split temporally such that data from the four latest time windows (between Thursday, March 28, 2024 2:10 PM and Wednesday, March 27, 2024 8:10 AM) was selected as test data, amounting to 730 samples. The remaining data was stratified based on time window and cluster. 730 samples, to be used as the validation set, were selected such that each time window and cluster were sampled at least once. The remaining data, amounting to 3,589 samples, was assigned as training data. Country distributions for the splits are shown in Figure 1B-D. Detailed counts are available in Supplementary Tables 1-3.

Following topic diversification, as detailed in Section 3.2, the AskNews-NER-v0 dataset comprised 5,049 articles covering 73 unique topics (Supplementary Figure 2) and originating from 125 different countries. The distribution of countries in the full dataset, as well as in the train, test, and validation splits, are shown in Supplementary Tables 1-3. meta-llama/Meta-Llama-3-70B-Instruct [AI@Meta, 2024] was used for labeling entities in these news articles, resulting in the entity types shown in Supplementary Figure 3.
Supplementary Table 2: Country distribution. Article frequency for the mid 51-100 countries represented in the AskNews-NER-v0 dataset. Continued from Supplementary Table 1.
Supplementary Table 3: Country distribution. Article frequency for the bottom 101-125 countries represented in the AskNews-NER-v0 dataset. Continued from Supplementary Tables 1 and 2.

The dataset was split temporally such that data from the four latest time windows (between Thursday, March 28, 2024 2:10 PM and Wednesday, March 27, 2024 8:10 AM) was selected as test data, amounting to 730 samples. The remaining data was stratified based on time window and cluster. 730 samples, to be used as the validation set, were selected such that each time window and cluster were sampled at least once. The remaining data, amounting to 3,589 samples, was assigned as training data. Country distributions for the splits are shown in Figure 1B-D. Detailed counts are available in Supplementary Tables 1-3.

Following topic diversification, as detailed in Section 3.2, the AskNews-NER-v0 dataset comprised 5,049 articles covering 73 unique topics (Supplementary Figure 2) and originating from 125 different countries. The distribution of countries in the full dataset, as well as in the train, test, and validation splits, are shown in Supplementary Tables 1-3. meta-llama/Meta-Llama-3-70B-Instruct [AI@Meta, 2024] was used for labeling entities in these news articles, resulting in the entity types shown in Supplementary Figure 3.

references: Table 1: Zero-shot performance on 18 NER datasets. Performance comparison between NuNERZero-span, GLiNER base models ("v2.1"), and fine-tuned models ("News") on common NER benchmarks as well as on the test split of the AskNews-NER-v0 dataset. Bold indicates the highest score per dataset. Green and red values indicate increase or decrease in score for the fine-tuned model compared to the base model. Comparison also to GLiNER-v1 models are found in Supplementary Table 4. Commit hashes for all models are found in Supplementary Table 5.

The fine-tuned NER models were evaluated in a zero-shot context on common NER benchmarks. Supplementary Table 4 shows the scores for GLiNER v1 models, GLiNER v2.1 models, and the fine-tuned models on 18 NER benchmark datasets. Performance improvements for the fine-tuned models compared to the base models (GLiNER v2.1) are found in Table 1.

Supplementary Table 4: Zero-shot performance on 18 NER datasets. Comparison between base models (S - GLiNER-Small, M - GLiNER-Medium, L - GLiNER-Large) and fine-tuned models ("News"). Performance on the test split of the anNER-v0 dataset is shown at the bottom. Bold indicates the highest score per dataset. Commit hashes for all models are found in Supplementary Table 5.

For reproducibility purposes, we provide the Huggingface commit hashes for the models used in this paper (Supplementary Table 5). The GLiNER models were refactored from the versions published in Zaratiana et al. [2023] before being published to Huggingface. As we have evaluated our fine-tuned models compared to the versions available on Huggingface, we also compare benchmark scores of the GLiNER models available on Huggingface to those reported in in Supplementary Tables 7 and 6.

Supplementary Table 6: Comparison between models currently available on Huggingface  and scores reported in Table 1 in Zaratiana et al. [2023]. Zero-shot performance on Out-of-Domain NER benchmark datasets for the different model sizes (S- small, M - medium, L - large). Bold indicates the highest score per dataset. Green and red values indicate increase or decrease in score for  models compared to published scores. Commit hashes for the  models are found in Supplementary Table 5.

Supplementary Table 7: Comparison between large model currently available on Huggingface  and scores reported in Table 2 in Zaratiana et al. [2023]. Zero-shot performance on 20 NER benchmark datasets for Large models. Bold indicates the highest score per dataset. Green and red values indicate increase or decrease in score for  models compared to published scores. The commit hash for the  model is found in Supplementary Table 5.

references: We evaluated our fine-tuned models in a zero-shot context on common NER benchmarks, as were presented in (Zaratiana et al., 2023). These benchmark datasets include the Out-of-Domain (OOD) NER Benchmark (Table 2), which contains seven NER datasets from the CrossNER (Liu et al., 2020) and MIT (Liu et al., 2013a, b) benchmark collections, as well as 18 NER datasets (Table 1) that are commonly used to train NER models.

Tables 1 and 2 show that our fine-tuned models improve the performance of the base models by 4.6%, on average, and outperforms other LLM-based models. The fine-tuned small model showed increased scores of 2.5 points (5.5%) on the 18 NER datasets and 0.9 points (1.7%) on the OOD benchmarks. The scores for the fine-tuned medium model also showed improvements with an additional 3.3 points (7.2%) on the 18 NER datasets and 2.1 points (3.6%) on the OOD benchmarks. Similarly, the fine-tuning of the large model improved the score by and 3.3 points (7.3%) on the 18 NER datasets and 1 point (1.7%) on the OOD benchmarks.

Note that the performance of the GLiNER models detailed in Zaratiana et al. (2023) does not align perfectly with the scores presented here in Tables 1 and 2 as the GLiNER models were refactored before publication to Huggingface (see discussion in GitHub Issue here:  Reproduction questions #54). As our models were fine-tuned on the Huggingface versions, we evaluate those models rather than present the previous scores. A comparison between the scores published in Zaratiana et al. (2023) and in this paper can be found in Supplementary Tables 6 and 7.

The fine-tuned NER models were evaluated in a zero-shot context on common NER benchmarks. Supplementary Table 4 shows the scores for GLiNER v1 models, GLiNER v2.1 models, and the fine-tuned models on 18 NER benchmark datasets. Performance improvements for the fine-tuned models compared to the base models (GLiNER v2.1) are found in Table 1.

references: We evaluated our fine-tuned models in a zero-shot context on common NER benchmarks, as were presented in (Zaratiana et al., 2023). These benchmark datasets include the Out-of-Domain (OOD) NER Benchmark (Table 2), which contains seven NER datasets from the CrossNER (Liu et al., 2020) and MIT (Liu et al., 2013a, b) benchmark collections, as well as 18 NER datasets (Table 1) that are commonly used to train NER models.

Tables 1 and 2 show that our fine-tuned models improve the performance of the base models by 4.6%, on average, and outperforms other LLM-based models. The fine-tuned small model showed increased scores of 2.5 points (5.5%) on the 18 NER datasets and 0.9 points (1.7%) on the OOD benchmarks. The scores for the fine-tuned medium model also showed improvements with an additional 3.3 points (7.2%) on the 18 NER datasets and 2.1 points (3.6%) on the OOD benchmarks. Similarly, the fine-tuning of the large model improved the score by and 3.3 points (7.3%) on the 18 NER datasets and 1 point (1.7%) on the OOD benchmarks.

Note that the performance of the GLiNER models detailed in Zaratiana et al. (2023) does not align perfectly with the scores presented here in Tables 1 and 2 as the GLiNER models were refactored before publication to Huggingface (see discussion in GitHub Issue here:  Reproduction questions #54). As our models were fine-tuned on the Huggingface versions, we evaluate those models rather than present the previous scores. A comparison between the scores published in Zaratiana et al. (2023) and in this paper can be found in Supplementary Tables 6 and 7.
